Award.AwardTitle: SEES Fellows: Living with locusts: Training an ecophysiologist to incorporate bioeconomic modeling and collaborative with applied food security and agricultural agencies
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Award from the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows Program), Dr. Arianne Cease from Arizona State University will investigate the interesting dynamic coupling between land use for agriculture (grazing of livestock) and the outbreak of swarms of locusts. This award is supported by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences and the Office of Integrative and International Activities.

The proposed work will (1) develop a bioeconomic model to investigate the interactions between human behavior, insect-nutrient relations, and food security, via mathematical modeling of this complex system; (2) investigate how rangeland management impacts Oedalus locust outbreaks and migration through changes in macronutrients available in their food plants; and (3) work with stakeholders to devise policy which takes into account livestock-locust interactions and disseminate these findings through aid agencies to populations impacted by locusts.

The aim of studies like that proposed in this work is to develop better land management practices that take into account the unusually complex couplings between agricultural activities and ecological systems.

Dr. Cease will be working with collaborators Prof. Jon Harrison of the School of Life Sciences of Arizona State University as well as Prof. Eli Fenechel at the School of Forestry and Environmental Studies of Yale University. The work will also involve collaboration with Profs. James Elser and Asst. Dean Charles Kazilek at Arizona State University; Prof. Stephen J. Simpson of the School of Biological Sciences, University of Sydney and Dr. James D. Woodman of the Australian Plague Locust Commission; and Dr. Todd Crosby of USAID/Project Yaajeenda and Dr. Aliou Diongue of the Plant Protection Service, Senegal.

This project is supported under the NSF Science, Engineering and Education for Sustainability Fellows (SEES Fellows) program, with the goal of helping to enable discoveries needed to inform actions that lead to environmental, energy and societal sustainability while creating the necessary workforce to address these challenges. With SEES Fellows support, this project will enable a promising early career researcher to establish themselves in an independent research career related to sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Major goals addressed

  • Understand how agricultural land use influences locust outbreaks through changes in plant nutrition in locusts found in China, Australia, Senegal, and South America.
  • Test the effects of nutrition on locust growth, survival, and migratory capacity.
  • Develop models describing feedbacks among locusts, nitrogen cycling, and grassland management.
  • Work with farmers and government agencies to develop new solutions for locust management.

 

Summary numbers

  • Peer-reviewed publications: 8 published, 1 in review, 3 in preparation
  • National and international presentations: 22
  • Students trained: 5 graduate, 8 undergraduate
  • Organizations collaborated with: 15 organizations across 5 countries

 

Intellectual Merit

We are one of the first groups to conduct field and lab-based comparative physiology on non-model locust species across multiple continents. We are uncovering the physiological and ecological and nutritional mechanisms responsible for insect outbreaks and migration. Our field demonstrations showing that many locust species are actually harmed by excessive nitrogen is becoming a new paradigm for plant-insect interaction research.

 

This project integrates novel fundamental research from multiple disciplines to improve our ability to manage social-ecological systems. In doing so, it is one of the first to apply both highly-controlled lab and field-based techniques to connect physiological mechanisms regulating locust outbreaks and migration to agricultural practices and livelihoods.

 

This fellowship has allowed the PI to develop a new initiative at ASU—the Global Locust Initiative—whose purpose is to assist universities, government and nongovernment agencies, and agricultural communities to forge new partnerships that seek to better integrate locust research and management. GLI is based on three pillars: advancing research, creating and maintaining a global network, and developing local solutions to the global challenge of locust plagues. www.locust.asu.edu

 

Broader Impacts

Training: Through this grant, many trainees at ASU have had significant opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science. Five graduate and 8 undergraduate students were engaged in weekly lab meetings, running experiments, and working on the interdisciplinary team. Most students also assisted in designing experiments and interpreting results.

 

Outreach: We have been invited to present our research at numerous ASU affiliated venues as an example of a complex sustainability challenge, representing ASU’s Global Institute of Sustainability.

 

Community impact: Throughout this project, we worked integratively with local and national organizations in the regions where we conducted research. We met with partners regularly to discuss research design and disseminated results through culturally-appropriate mechanisms. For example, for the farming communities in Senegal, M.S. student Mira Word created pamphlets in French and Wolof (the local language) describing our project and the results. We held town hall meetings at the two villages where we collected data in 2016. We handed out pamphlets, discussed results, and received feedback from the farmers and village leaders. We held additional meetings with the DPV (Senegalese plant health directorate) where we delivered additional pamphlets to be shared with interested farmers and discussed further ways to integrate our research and DPV objectives and activities.

 

Locusts continue to have devastating impacts on agriculture and food security around the globe and especially in subsistence farming communities. Currently, best practices include diligent monitoring for early outbreaks and targeted control involving pesticide application. However, chemical pesticides can be ineffective and have far-reaching human and environmental health impacts. Additionally, locusts are a continental-level problem that requires coordinated responses across boundaries by individuals and governments. Our team’s research has paved the way for an innovative interdisciplinary, systems, and applied approach that targets sustainable land use as a tool.
